Author: joey#9690
Content:
Hi, FLO team guy here, I can answer some of the questions posted above. The tl;dr is that apps on the FLO blockchain have features allowing users to increase the security of our chain. Removing those features is a dealbreaker. 

> why would they want to be controlling notary nodes? the idea is to not have to worry about such things
Caltech, Medici, and Alexandria projects all expressed deep concern about not having any option to allow users to participate in the security of the network. We don't want to "not worry about the security", we want to build applications in which our users can participate in the security of the network the same day that they learn about the network. In fact, in all of those projects, users are encouraged and rewarded for participating in the security of the network at the protocol level.

> they wanted duke to basically work for free
> they only had $500 
The offer was $500 in BTC upfront plus any amount of FLO you felt reasonable after the job is complete. I was asking for an hour a week in a conference call to help review our code and answer questions. I think our offer was fair, and actually better in terms of dollars per hour than a fulltime engagement where you are coding for months and responsible for delivering the entire completed software.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nothing about using dPoW stops people from securing the FLO blockchain. it is not needed to invade into notary space to secure things

Author: joey#9690
Content: I think we could unpack that statement and find points to agree and disagree on but it's moot. There is a philosophical disagreement stemming from the wishes of the applications and users in our community

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @joey  traditional PoW is still required,  can you explain how they would not have a hand in the security of their own network?  And how that having FLO controlling a Notary node would be that hand in the security?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I think there is a misunderstanding about the nature of the notary nodes

Author: joey#9690
Content: If FLO is susceptible to a 51% attack and the notary nodes help prevent a 51% attack then having control over a notary node is significant in the context of our chain's security

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: The mechanism by which Notary nodes help other chains  secure against 51% attacks is through group signed tx ( vast oversimplification ) onto bitcoin chain.  3rd party chains piggyback through the cascade effect.   1/64 of possible signatures is not any sort of hand of security.  Notary nodes are elected delegates,  which have a mining privilege in the Komodo chain ,simply handing over a notary node is the equivalent of paying you to secure to your chain.  If you want control of a Notary node your community can gather votes to be elected as one.   What you are paying for with DPoW integration not only making FLO compatible but the running of FLO nodes on all Notary servers, a necessary audit to confirm that running your nodes isn't going to compromise our setups.  500$ doesn't come close to the costs of integration and while yes you offered FLO which I'm sure could be taken in part,  the truth is much would have to hit the market to recover costs which would not be beneficial for FLOs price.   TLDR :  notaries secure through sending tx in Komodo chain of FLO blockhashes to prevent private mined 51% attacks and mitigate other attacks controlling one node of 64 does nothing in that process and the cost of integration is much more than offered even at modest IT rates

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: 300kmd is cheaper than $500 anyway :trollface:

Author: joey#9690
Content: I don't understand, who is talking about integration costs?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: That's just the Komodo cost of the notarization itself not all the things that go into it

Author: joey#9690
Content: How is that relevant?

Author: joey#9690
Content: I also understand how the system works, but that was a good high level overview

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: You mentioned the offer being fair earlier on,  this is one of the points of contention in integration isn't it?

Author: joey#9690
Content: Duke asked for $1500 up front for a full integration (2 month full time engagement), and my offer was $500 up front for 1 hour a week conference call. Does that seem unreasonable?

Author: joey#9690
Content: In the second case, we would be doing 100% of the coding

Author: joey#9690
Content: I think I made that very clear in my original comment

Author: joey#9690
Content: Integration costs were not a point of contention by the way

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Compared to what will be charged in the future 1500 is a steal.   Regardless,  FLO would still have a hand in accepting notarized blockhashes without control of a Notary node,  there is nothing about a Notarization that affects FLOs consensus mechanism ,  basically all we do is write public blockhashes.  Still up to your community to mine blocks.  Still up to the community to agree upon notarization in the event of the attack,  in fact without FLO communities accepted public blockhashes ,  done through consensus mechanism which Komodo has no hand in, what purpose does DPoW  have?   FLOs base security determines the effectiveness of DPoW

Author: joey#9690
Content: We agreed to his original ask

Author: joey#9690
Content: He suggested taking a lesser role due to his workload

Author: joey#9690
Content: Anyway, the point about being able to contribute to the security of the network is a philosophical disagreement that the devs building the apps running on FLO have with the notary node system

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
@joey  Interesting discussion!
I'm also interested in making use of dPOW security and in particiating as a NN.
As mentioned, surely there are many others out there among all of the projects that would like the same.  And yet there are only 30 (+3?) NN positions available at the next election.  
In my case, for practical reasons, I view these as 2 separate matters.
If I were to consider them as one in the same I would need to seriously consider the advice from jl777 above and create my own network notarizing to BTC. Not a realistic possibility for me at the moment.
The #notarynode channel is open to all to participate in.  Of course, that's not actually sending transactions to BTC (who does that is rightly decided by the Komodo community).  It can be a form of active participation by those who choose to use it as such though.
This discussion is useful for me to clarify the best course of action for the near future.
Hopefully further discussion generates other ideas that I can use :)
btw FLO sounds like an interesting project!

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I like it to,  I hope we can work together in someway in the future even if we don't agree on some things.   Real coins with communities are special,  especially after this ICO craze.

Author: joey#9690

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @CrisF  the reason for only half of the notaries being reelected is for a logistic reason,  imagine the headache if a majority of the nodes were new ,  catching everyone up to speed with what is going on especially with the rate James puts out stuff would be very stressful and would interrupt operations,  keeping a core of already trained nodes mitigates this issue greatly

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: @joey if I get your point, the main issue raised is the decentralisation of the dPoW/Notary Nodes? Please correct me if I get it wrong. I can say next bit of my comment once you answer this 🙂

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @joey Yeah, I've found the resources and forum for ideas here to be quite amazing.  And the opportunity Komodo is providing for people like me, with ideas but without deep technical knowledge or resources, is truly something that can make those ideas a reality.

Author: joey#9690
Content: @grewalsatinder the problem is we have 3 production apps using our blockchain and they each incentivize security of our network at the protocol level by contributing a % of sales to mining rewards. Adding another layer of security (notary nodes) without a way to contribute to the strength of that second-layer security breaks the security guarantee of the apps we've built. Technically, we don't *need* to implement anything additional, but the app developers have voiced their opinion that the guarantee of increased security based on sales % should not be altered. As someone else here said, it's an idealistic decision more than a practical one, but such is the will of the community. If it were up to me things would have been done differently, but I'm not the dictator of FLO, otherwise I would have named it joeycoin 😉

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @polycryptoblog Yes, I feel that the current system of keeping on notaries is good for many reasons.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I guess where I am confused is how DPoW affects that system at all?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: The second layer is directly dependent on the first.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @joey Perhaps, when you present your finding from here, the app developers will be able to come up with some solutions that suit their need?  That could then be further discussed here, to all of our benefit.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:
@joey okay, still unclear if it's decentralisation issue or not. Anyway, there are some options to consider.
- a 3rd party project like FLO can also setup their own independent Notary Nodes (64).
  - implement dPoW to FLO code
  - let community elect these 64 notary nodes. however the voting is managed to elect these notary nodes is up to the project and the community.
  - benefit is still getting your own set of notary nodes.
  - but at cost of btc/kmd notarisations paid by these set of notary nodes.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: When all the ahrd work has already been done, to support multiple iguana networks, I dont understand why we are not using it.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Every time you add more coins to the KMD 64 notary nodes, it takes away secudity form KMD. That  is very bad.

Author: joey#9690
Content: @blackjok3r do you mean it takes away security because the cost of resources to audit the code and upkeep grows per project added?

Author: joey#9690
Content: or because it's more surface area for attack?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: That is one aspect... .also running millions of coins from the same set of pubkeys causes all kinds of issues. I have fixed this as best as it possibly cna be done, with a patch to iguana that uses `lockunspent` to stop utxo conflicts, but there is really no reason not to just use more sets of keys.
